tweet: I want to thank you for taking the time to read today’s #FridayFocus on an extremely important topic.  If you have any questions or want more information on immigration legislation or data, please don’t hesitate to reach out to my office.

Debate on immigration policy frequently becomes heated but I ask that you keep the information I shared today in mind.  Our country has provided countless immigrants with an opportunity for a better life and our communities have benefited as a result.
H.R. 6 passed in the House of Representatives earlier this month and has not yet been scheduled for a vote in the Senate.

H.R. 6 doesn’t allow any of these people to “cut the line” and receive their citizenship on some sort of fast track, the process would take years. It simply rectifies a horrible mistake within our broken immigration system that left so many people in an uncertain state.

Jersey City is the home of 3,800 H.R. 6 protected immigrants, on avg the Dreamers arrived when they were 9 years old & the avg TPS recipient has been in here since 1995. These immigrants pay $48.6 million in Federal taxes and $23.7 million in State & local taxes each year.

Newark is home to 4,900 H.R. 6 protected immigrants.  On average the Dreamers arrived when they were 9 and most TPS recipients came to Newark in 2000. They pay $22.2 million in Federal taxes and $15.2 million in State and local taxes every year.

Elizabeth is home to 5,400 H.R. 6 protected immigrants, on average the Dreamers arrived at the age of 9 and TPS recipients came in 1997. These 5,400 people pay $35.4 million in Federal taxes and $21.3 million in State and local taxes every year.

Out of all the members on the House Budget Committee, I represent the district with the most individuals (19,500) covered by these programs and we would be severely impacted if the protections were removed.

This is why I am proud to be an original cosponsor of H.R. 6, the American Dream and Promise Act of 2019. This legislation would help to create a pathway to legal permanent resident status for Dreamers and TPS recipients.

We can argue about what immigration reform should look like, but we can’t deny that there are good people who would get “in line” if there was a line for them at all and that our immigration system has failed them.
Both groups contribute to our economy, work hard to improve their communities, and are Americans in their hearts.

Within our flourishing immigrant population, there is a subset that faces even more obstacles, Dreamers & TPS recipients.  Dreamers were brought to this country as kids & only know America as home while some TPS recipients have been here for decades after fleeing violence & chaos
These tax dollars fund infrastructure improvements, better school systems, Social Security, and countless other initiatives.

Beyond creating jobs, immigrants in the 8th District pay over $3.3 billion in taxes every year. This money goes to fund programs that positively impact our communities, and millions of Americans across the country.

If you walk down the street, chances are you’ll pass at least one business that was created by an immigrant or pass a neighbor who works at one.  The 8th District is home to nearly 12,000 of immigrant entrepreneurs.
Despite being less than 14% of the total population, immigrants make up about 30% of all new entrepreneurs.  We see the hard work of these entrepreneurs every day in the 8th District.
Stabilizing populations allow communities to attract businesses, create jobs, employ individuals and boost local government revenues - allowing everyone to benefit from increased investment.

In fact, the working-age population is only expected to grow by .3 percent each year for the next decade but immigrants will make up 85% of that growth.  This growth also prevents population decline in rural areas, which helps stabilize local populations.
This leads to lower productivity, an erosion of business dynamism, and a general decrease to our economic growth. Immigrants help make up for this shortfall of workers when they join the workforce.

Beyond the links between immigration and lower crime rates, immigration helps make our nation more productive.  Our workforce is aging and as baby boomers retire and birth rates fall, our working-age population shrinks.

According to one study by the @NewAmericanEcon , 9 out of the 10 American cities that received the largest influx of refugees between 2006 and 2015 saw violent crime rates drop over this same period. pic.twitter.com/mYZHnp1B7u

As I said on Wednesday, I just don’t buy the claim that immigrants are criminals and the facts back me up.  On average, cities with substantial immigrant populations have lower crime rates than those with small immigrant populations.

The President chooses to characterize immigrants as criminals – a threat to our society, but as an immigrant myself, I know this is not the case. Immigrants are hard-working and patriotic contributors to our economy.
They are your neighbors, classmates, colleagues, and family members. Unfortunately, the Trump administration wants to stop immigrants from coming into the country.

The 8th District of New Jersey is a perfect example of how immigrants enrich our culture and contribute to our economy every day. Our district is home to over 330,000 immigrants who make up nearly 44% of our population.

The United States has always been a country that welcomes immigrants and gives them the opportunity to make a difference for their families, communities, and the country they have chosen to call home.
Today my #FridayFocus will take an in depth look at some of the positive contributions that immigrants make to both our society and our economy.

On Wednesday, the @HouseBudgetDems Committee held a hearing focusing on the positive economic impact that immigrants have on our economy. I spoke about my family’s journey – the journey that so many of our families have made as they sought out a better life.

Thank you for joining me for this week’s #FridayFocus discussing the realities of poverty in America. Congress must continue to help those in need.

Living in, or at the edges of, poverty is a reality for many Americans and I am dedicated to fighting for programs that help those in need. No one in the 8th District or across the country should have to worry about food and shelter.
The Child Care and Development Block Grant helps fund services and programs that prepare children for success in school. In New Jersey there are almost 30,000 families enrolled in the program.

CHIP, the Children’s Health Insurance Program, along with Medicaid, provides health coverage to millions of children across the country, and SSI, Supplemental Security Income, helps provide funds to seniors who are unable to work.

The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) offers nutrition assistance to about 43 million families each year, and kept 8.4 million people out of poverty, in 2015 alone. In New Jersey that year there were over 900,000 people receiving benefits.
During the ongoing appropriations process I signed letters requesting funding for these programs, among others. Because I know the real impact they can make on people’s everyday lives.
I have been, and remain, a vigilant supporter of programs such as SNAP, CHIP, SSI, and the Child Care & Development Block Grant.

Furthermore, the Administration also wants to impose harsher work requirements for people who seek benefits. This would lower the amount of people eligible for benefits and is a cruel form of discrimination against those who are disabled and unable to work.

The White House also wants to implement an $8.6 billion spending cut to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. This would decrease available funds for grants and programs that help people afford housing.

If the Administration does change the measurement data, 300,000 children and 150,000 seniors would lose their health coverage from Medicaid. This is without the President’s proposed $1.5 trillion cut from Medicaid, which would cause even more people to lose their health coverage.

The current measurement of poverty in the U.S. uses the Consumer Price Index but this Administration wants to switch to an alternative measure of inflation that would decrease the amount of people eligible for certain programs such as Medicaid and SNAP.

In 2017, the 8th District had a poverty rate of 15.5%, and 22.5% of children were living in poverty. However, the Trump Administration wants to build more barriers and make it more difficult for families and individuals to sign up for and receive benefits.

Therefore, there are millions more Americans who are struggling to make ends meet but are not categorized as under the poverty line, meaning they cannot receive benefits from the federal government, which in turn, punishes them financially.

This number does not consider the current reality for a family that may be enduring hardships but doesn’t fall below the official poverty line. The National Center for Children in Poverty estimates a family requires an income of twice the poverty level to support their needs.

Unfortunately, almost 40 million Americans, about 12% of the population, fall below the poverty line. Even more frustrating is the realization that nearly 1 in 5 children under the age of 18 live in poverty.

In the 116th Congress, my colleagues and I have made it our highest priority to pass legislation that improves daily life for all Americans. Helping working families become financially secure and providing them with extra resources is one part of this mission.

This week @HouseBudgetDems held a hearing focused on the economic realities for families in America struggling to make ends meat. After hearing the heartfelt testimony by the witnesses, my #FridayFocus this week will take a deeper look at poverty in the U.S.

Thank you for joining me for this #FridayFocus to discuss how the appropriations process works and the importance of the process to our democratic system.

The appropriations process is an important aspect of Congress’s Constitutional power of the purse. Funding levels determined during the appropriations process are crucial to the performance of agencies and implementation of public programs.
Upon both chambers adopting an identical spending bill, the bill is then sent to the President for his signature or veto.

Both chambers must pass an identical bill before it can be signed into law. If there are differences the chambers can then continue to pass amendments to each other until issues are resolved or can hold a conference of members in order to get an agreement.

Once the spending bill passes the House, it is sent to the Senate for consideration. The Senate can also make changes to the bill in the form of amendments. These amendments usually become the topic of debate between the two chambers.
When a minibus like this comes to the House Floor members are given the chance to offer amendments and change funding levels of the bill before it receives a vote.

The debate this week centered on a minibus, a package of 4 smaller appropriations bills. This minibus, H.R. 2740, considered spending limits for Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Defense, State and Foreign Operations, and Energy and Water Development.

Following passage in the Appropriations Committee the spending bills will be brought to the House floor for a vote. The spending packages can be voted on individually, all-together, or in smaller groupings known as a “minibus”.
Each subcommittee will then mark up their spending proposal before sending it to the full committee for consideration.

Next, each subcommittee will create a budget that allocates their total predetermined funding to the programs and agencies under their jurisdiction. This power of Congress to determine spending levels is vital for enforcing checks and balances.

Some of the letters I signed supported funding for medical research, affordable housing programs, community health centers, community development grants, law enforcement grants, and gun violence prevention measures.
Once these letters are circulated, members formally submit their funding priorities to the 12 subcommittees.
The appropriations process begins in the House, it is important the proposed funding levels reflect the needs of constituents, not just the White House’s desired budget.
Members lead & sign onto letters to the Appropriations Committee outlining requests important to their district.

The appropriations process began a few months ago. After reviewing the President’s proposed budget, Members of Congress have an opportunity to submit funding requests to support various programs, agencies, and priorities.

This week, the House of Representatives started debating amendments on our first appropriations package for FY 2020. For this week’s #FridayFocus let’s take a deeper look into how the appropriations process works.

The power of Congress to fund the government is an important aspect of checks and balances laid out in the constitution. It is the duty of Congress to ensure that the government is funded appropriately.

The legislation being considered is a minibus, a grouping of four smaller appropriation bills packaged into one single bill. This will enable the House to pass the appropriations with just one vote, rather than voting on each appropriations bill separately.
H.R. 2740 considers appropriations for certain departments of the federal government. The Constitution give the Congress the powers of the purse, which enables us to fund the federal government.

This is just the beginning of the work left to do in Congress. Life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness includes a person’s inherent ability to choose how they identify and who they love.

The fight for LGBTQ+ protections also extends beyond our borders. I have joined my colleagues in sending letters to the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo bringing to his attention LGBTQ+ abuses by the governments of Chechnya and Brazil and demanding quick action.

I cosponsored H.R. 2775, which would add gender and sexual identity protections to the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act and create queer inclusive reporting standards for the Department of Health and Human Services.
H.R 2775, the Protecting LGBTQ+ Youth Act, addresses the increased risks of abuse and negligence queer youth face in unwelcoming homes
As a cosponsor, I am outraged that any American could be denied a home because of hate.

H.R. 2402, the Fair and Equal Housing Act, is a standalone provision of the Equality Act that would ensure no person is turned away from housing because of bigotry against sexual orientation and gender identity.
It is time now for the Senate to take up H.R. 5 and enact these landmark federal protections into law.

H.R. 5 is a comprehensive federal package that would forbid discrimination in housing, services, and employment on the basis of sexual and gender identity. As an original cosponsor, I proudly voted for its passage.
Last month’s historic House passage of H.R. 5, the Equality Act, demonstrates the political support for legislation enshrining equal protection under the law for LGBTQ+ Americans.

I thank all of those who put the needs of others before their own 75 years ago, and remember those who made the ultimate sacrifice in the face of such a harrowing challenge .
Few moments hold such historic significance, that in one of history’s darkest hours, millions of young men and women chose to unite and rebuild a free world is a remarkable achievement.
Their unthinkable sacrifice, dedication to country and fellow soldiers, and commitment to upholding freedom and democracy helped them to topple the Nazi regime.

These brave soldiers took up this task in the name of freedom, to fight for the values and ideals they cherished against the dimming force of oppression and authoritarianism. Today I remember and thank those soldiers who stormed the beaches during D-Day.
American, British, Canadian, French, and soldiers of many other nationalities stormed Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno, and Sword beaches in France despite fierce German resistance.
75 years ago today, thousands of courageous young men embarked on an invasion of Normandy, France, while thousands more dropped in behind enemy lines.

As the representative for the 8th district, the home of many hard-working immigrant families, I am proud that the House is voting on this legislation and call on Senator McConnell to stop blocking legislation from the Senate floor.

H.R. 6 would also help to create a path to LPR status for those who were eligible for TPS and DED on January 1, 2017 and have been here for three years, but were unable to take advantage of the programs due to President Trump’s policies.

Dreamers who came to the U.S. before the age of 18 and have been here for more than 4 years while completing educational benchmarks will be able to apply for ‘conditional’ LPR status, while full LPR status will be granted as dreamers continue with their professional careers.

That is why I am proud to be a cosponsor of H.R. 6, the American Dream and Promise Act. This legislation establishes a process for eligible Dreamers to apply for lawful permanent resident (LPR) status, eventually allowing them to obtain citizenship.
Since taking over the House, our democratic majority has consistently considered and debated legislation that seeks to restore the gaping holes left by this administration’s actions.
Dreamers, TPS, and DED holders have been left floundering by the Trump Administration and are a casualty of this President’s xenophobic fear-mongering.

President Trump has also ended the Temporary Protected Status (TPS) and the Deferred Enforced Departure Program (DED) for many people who fled their homes years ago due to turmoil and have since made America home.
DACA allowed our neighbors, classmates, colleagues, and friends to come out of the shadows and continue contributing to our economy and society.
These Dreamers came to America as small children, through no fault of their own. Some did not even know they weren’t citizens until they were old enough to get their drivers license.
Two years ago, President Trump terminated the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, sending millions of young people, who call America home, into a future of fear and uncertainty.
